description: Amid ongoing protests and distrust of the Council, public debates intensify in neighborhoods and gathering spots about Stenograd's future: complete abolition of the BCI or pursuit of digital autonomy.

Rada Miskovic organizes a covert meeting with returned citizens and analog resistance figures. Together, they draft an open declaration advocating for the right to disconnect and self-organized analog communities.

Rada publicly releases the digital autonomy declaration, urging all citizens to choose between limited BCI participation and disconnecting to join new analog neighborhoods. The call gains rapid support as symbols of autonomy appear across the city.

Hundreds of families publicly opt out of the BCI, marking their homes and local spaces with chalk. Volunteer-led analog communities organize essential services through direct barter and cooperation, testing the feasibility of dual systems.

As resource distribution shifts, some BCI-aligned neighborhoods face shortages while analog areas adapt quickly. The Council mediates a tense compromise, establishing basic rules for coexistence between digital and analog societies in Stenograd.
